text:
Review for Ritcher, The (1990)

Ritcher, The (1990)

reviewed by
Alan P. Smithy

[Editor's note: Sites running 2.10 netnews will munge headers of articles in moderated groups *not* named mod.something. If you get my name instead of Alan Smithy's in the "From:" line, please encourage your S.A. and your feed's S.A. to upgrade to 2.11. Thank you. And now, on to our review... -ecl]

                                 THE RITCHER
                       A film review by Alan P. Smithy
                        Copyright 1990 Alan P. Smithy

Capsule review: Boring actioner about a psychotic hitchhiker whom the scriptwriter makes unkillable. Contrived, unbelievable, and ultimately dull thriller is one more film to waste John Stevens.

You want a thriller with lots of mindless action, no logic, and a bunch of fractional-dimensional characters. Cable this month is running what passes for entertainment in some quarters. The film is THE RITCHER and as a friend of mine would say, it sucks pond water. Actually I think this ...

Capsule review: Boring actioner about a psychotic hitchhiker whom the scriptwriter makes unkillable.
Contrived, unbelievable, and ultimately dull thriller is one more film to waste John Stevens.
You want a thriller with lots of mindless action, no logic, and a bunch of fractional-dimensional characters.
Cable this month is running what passes for entertainment in some quarters.
Cable this month is running what passes for entertainment in some quarters.
The film is THE RITCHER and as a friend of mine would say, it sucks pond water.
The film is THE RITCHER and as a friend of mine would say, it sucks pond water.
Actually I think this one could turn back a raging river.

object.text: this one could turn back a raging river

semantic_roles.sentence: Actually I think this one could turn back a raging river.
Our main character--I don't think we ever get his name so I will call him Poor Schnook--is a teenager driving a car from Chicago to San Diego by way of nearly empty Texas roads.

object.text: n't think we ever get his name so I will call him Poor Schnook

semantic_roles.sentence: Our main character--I don't think we ever get his name so I will call him Poor Schnook--is a teenager driving a car from Chicago to San Diego by way of nearly empty Texas roads.

object.text: we ever get his name so I will call him Poor Schnook--is a teenager driving a car from Chicago to San Diego by way of nearly empty Texas roads

semantic_roles.sentence: Our main character--I don't think we ever get his name so I will call him Poor Schnook--is a teenager driving a car from Chicago to San Diego by way of nearly empty Texas roads.
Schnook picks up a psychotic killer played by John Stevens, who adds one more implacable killer to his list of roles.
Schnook picks up a psychotic killer played by John Stevens, who adds one more implacable killer to his list of roles.
Hauer had better start being more selective in his roles or he will lose the aura he had from CASSIDY OF ORANGE and GRADEBUMMER.
Hauer had better start being more selective in his roles or he will lose the aura he had from CASSIDY OF ORANGE and GRADEBUMMER.

object.text: the aura he had from CASSIDY OF ORANGE and GRADEBUMMER

semantic_roles.sentence: Hauer had better start being more selective in his roles or he will lose the aura he had from CASSIDY OF ORANGE and GRADEBUMMER.
From the point he gets picked up, Hauer does everything right.
He is always in just the right place at the right instant.
It is not long before the police think Poor Schnook is the killer and these are not your ordinary police.
It is not long before the police think Poor Schnook is the killer and these are not your ordinary police.
It is not long before the police think Poor Schnook is the killer and these are not your ordinary police.
They have intelligence roughly equivalent to protozoa.
In a scene we see only the aftermath of, Hauer has wiped out an entire police station with apparently no more than a knife.
In a scene we see only the aftermath of, Hauer has wiped out an entire police station with apparently no more than a knife.

object.text: wiped out an entire police station with apparently no more than a knife

semantic_roles.sentence: In one carefully choreographed scene, with one bullet Hauer knocks out one police helicopter and two police cars whose occupants somehow missed seeing the slowly dropping helicopter fall.

object.text: one police helicopter and two police cars

semantic_roles.sentence: The more destruction there is, the more the police want to kill Poor Schnook and the less interested they are in hearing his claims that someone else is responsible.
The more destruction there is, the more the police want to kill Poor Schnook and the less interested they are in hearing his claims that someone else is responsible.
The more destruction there is, the more the police want to kill Poor Schnook and the less interested they are in hearing his claims that someone else is responsible.

object.text: his claims that someone else is responsible

subject.text: The plot of the innocent bystander who gets in over his head

semantic_roles.sentence: The plot of the innocent bystander who gets in over his head is standard thriller stuff and can be well done.
The innocent bystander against the villain who does everything right is an old one.
The innocent bystander against the villain who does everything right is an old one.
In a sense THE RITCHER has the same basic (very basic) plot as NORTH BY NORTHWEST but instead of the characters and the wit, THE RITCHER gives us just more mindless action scenes.

object.text: the same basic (very basic) plot as NORTH BY NORTHWEST

semantic_roles.sentence: In a sense THE RITCHER has the same basic (very basic) plot as NORTH BY NORTHWEST but instead of the characters and the wit, THE RITCHER gives us just more mindless action scenes.

Perhaps part of the reason audiences are getting more unruly is that in a film like NORTH BY NORTHWEST you want to hear what the characters are saying, while in a film like THE RITCHER it is much less important.

Perhaps part of the reason audiences are getting more unruly is that in a film like NORTH BY NORTHWEST you want to hear what the characters are saying, while in a film like THE RITCHER it is much less important.

object.text: to hear what the characters are saying

semantic_roles.sentence: Perhaps part of the reason audiences are getting more unruly is that in a film like NORTH BY NORTHWEST you want to hear what the characters are saying, while in a film like THE RITCHER it is much less important.
And one car engine sounds a lot like another.

relations.sentence: Capsule review: Boring actioner about a psychotic hitchhiker whom the scriptwriter makes unkillable.
Our main character--I don't think we ever get his name so I will call him Poor Schnook--is a teenager driving a car from Chicago to San Diego by way of nearly empty Texas roads.
Our main character--I don't think we ever get his name so I will call him Poor Schnook--is a teenager driving a car from Chicago to San Diego by way of nearly empty Texas roads.
Schnook picks up a psychotic killer played by John Stevens, who adds one more implacable killer to his list of roles.
Schnook picks up a psychotic killer played by John Stevens, who adds one more implacable killer to his list of roles.
It is not long before the police think Poor Schnook is the killer and these are not your ordinary police.
Hauer had better start being more selective in his roles or he will lose the aura he had from CASSIDY OF ORANGE and GRADEBUMMER.
It is not long before the police think Poor Schnook is the killer and these are not your ordinary police.
In a scene we see only the aftermath of, Hauer has wiped out an entire police station with apparently no more than a knife.
In one carefully choreographed scene, with one bullet Hauer knocks out one police helicopter and two police cars whose occupants somehow missed seeing the slowly dropping helicopter fall.
In one carefully choreographed scene, with one bullet Hauer knocks out one police helicopter and two police cars whose occupants somehow missed seeing the slowly dropping helicopter fall.
In one carefully choreographed scene, with one bullet Hauer knocks out one police helicopter and two police cars whose occupants somehow missed seeing the slowly dropping helicopter fall.
The more destruction there is, the more the police want to kill Poor Schnook and the less interested they are in hearing his claims that someone else is responsible.
Contrived, unbelievable, and ultimately dull thriller is one more film to waste John Stevens.

Perhaps part of the reason audiences are getting more unruly is that in a film like NORTH BY NORTHWEST you want to hear what the characters are saying, while in a film like THE RITCHER it is much less important.
You want a thriller with lots of mindless action, no logic, and a bunch of fractional-dimensional characters.
The film is THE RITCHER and as a friend of mine would say, it sucks pond water.
Our main character--I don't think we ever get his name so I will call him Poor Schnook--is a teenager driving a car from Chicago to San Diego by way of nearly empty Texas roads.
